item.title: Anna Sui Ushers Her Fashion Label Into the Future With the Help of Her Three Nieces
item.description: With the help of some of her nieces, the New York designer Anna Sui is steering her 45-year-old label into the future.
item.dc:creator: Yola Mzizi
item.media:credit: Braylen Dion for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna Sui, center, with her nieces, from left, Isabelle Sui, Jeannie Sui Wonders and Chase Sui Wonders.

item.title: Bad Bunny Fans Are Ready for ‘Benito Bowl’
item.description: For some viewers, the Super Bowl game is simply a prelude to a historic halftime show.
item.dc:creator: Sadiba Hasan

item.title: These A.I. Dreamers Don’t Fit the Stereotype
item.description: Young tech entrepreneurs in San Francisco are hoping to cash in, even as they wonder how artificial intelligence will affect society.
item.dc:creator: Guy Trebay
item.media:credit: Danielle Amy for The New York Times
item.media:description: The office of the San Francisco start-up Usul.

item.title: At the Puppy Bowl, the Athletes Are Up for Adoption
item.description: Public service announcement: The players on the field at this annual Super Bowl Sunday event are all up for adoption.
item.dc:creator: Scott Cacciola

item.title: Epstein Often Gifted Luxury Fashion to Curry Favor, Files Show
item.description: Goyard wallets, Apple Watches and cashmere sweaters were just some of the items sent to friends and associates.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher
item.media:credit: Neil Rasmus/Patrick McMullan, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Jeffrey Epstein was often photographed in a quarter-zip sweatshirt with his initials, J.E.E. Like many denizens of New York’s elite society, he was drawn to personalized products.

item.title: Pieter Mulier Named New Designer at Versace
item.description: In naming Pieter Mulier as its new chief creative officer, Versace showed that the fashion industry can be a chummy place.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher
item.media:credit: Valerio Mezzanotti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pieter Mulier on the runway at his Alaïa show in Paris in July 2021.

item.title: John F. Kennedy Jr. and Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy Celebrated at ‘Love Story’ Premiere
item.description: A party for Ryan Murphy’s new TV show about the couple drew a crowd that included Naomi Watts, Martha Stewart and Grace Gummer.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vadukul and Rebecca Smeyne
item.category: Love Story: John F. Kennedy Jr. & Carolyn Bessette (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Rebecca Smeyne for The New York Times

item.title: In Aspen, a Wintry Fashion Fantasia for Those Who Can Afford It
item.description: Celebrities and “Very Important Clients” gathered for a wintry spectacle arranged by the luxury brand Moncler.
item.dc:creator: Guy Trebay and Benjamin Rasmussen
item.media:description: The model Izabel Goulart at a party hosted by Moncler on a dude ranch in Colorado.

item.title: What Was the ‘Ocasio 64’ Reference on Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl Look?
item.description: And where did his suit come from? The answers may surprise.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: The 64 printed on Bad Bunny’s outfit gave the internet something to talk about.

item.title: Mack Hollins’s Red Jumpsuit and the Super Bowl Arrivals
item.description: The Super Bowl tunnel walk is the show before the show. Athletes arrived in head-to-toe monograms, shackles and leather.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher
item.media:credit: Charlie Riedel/Associated Press
item.media:description: New England Patriots wide receiver Mack Hollins wore a red jumpsuit with “Range 13” on the back, and his face covered.

item.title: Suzannah Lessard Dies at 81; Stanford White Descendant Who Wrote a Haunting Family Memoir
item.description: Growing up in a family of secrets, on a compound designed by her great-grandfather, made her a writer who investigated the built world with a wary eye.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.media:credit: Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Suzannah Lessard in 1996, on the balcony of the Players club in Manhattan, designed by her great-grandfather Stanford White.

item.title: Stop Pretending You ‘Need’ Your Phone ‘for Work’
item.description: Plus, summoning the courage to loaf off as flagrantly as the person in the next cubicle.
item.dc:creator: Max Read
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Margeaux Walter for The New York Times

item.title: Halle Berry Confirms Her Engagement to Van Hunt
item.description: The actress and producer confirmed her engagement on “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon,” unveiling an heirloom-style ring.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Vora

item.title: When They Were Broken Up, They Communicated Through Playlists
item.description: Daniel Schwaycer quietly made playlists about Elise Shanholtz. It took two years for her to realize they were about her.
item.dc:creator: Ama Sarpomaa

item.title: Seeking a Man Who Doesn’t Throw Tantrums
item.description: I had set my bar for relationships so low that any man who didn’t yell easily cleared it.
item.dc:creator: Denise Mills
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Heated? Yes. Rivalry? No.
item.description: Brock McGillis, a former professional hockey player who came out as gay in 2016, married Matthew Ward after a decade of ups and downs.
item.dc:creator: Sadiba Hasan
item.media:credit: Steph Martyniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brock McGillis, left, and Matthew Ward were married on Jan. 30 at the Windsor Arms Hotel in Toronto. The two connected in early 2016. Later that year, Mr. McGillis, a retired hockey player, came out publicly.

item.title: More Than a Decade Later, Nina Russell and Mainak Ghosh Found Each Other Again
item.description: Nina Russell and Mainak Ghosh met at a literary club at Yale. They wouldn’t become a couple until more than a decade later.
item.dc:creator: Stella Raine Chu

item.title: They Were Always on the Right Path
item.description: Dr. Peter Anderson, who had hiked 1,000 miles of the Appalachian Trail, helped Olivia Bergen prepare for her 2,200-mile solo trek.
item.dc:creator: Rosalie R. Radomsky

item.title: Test Your Brain Rot: Can You Use ‘Choppelganger’ In a Sentence?
item.description: This is a series about the mysteries of internet speak.
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times

item.title: What Does It Mean to Be Touch-Starved?
item.description: Research says that our health can suffer when we don’t experience enough physical contact. Here’s how to get more.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: Who Is That Masked Man? The Orchids Aren’t Telling.
item.description: Mr. Flower Fantastic, guest designer for the New York Botanical Garden’s Orchid Show, lets his art speak for itself, never showing his face.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Graeber
item.category: The Orchid Show: Mr. Flower Fantastics Concrete Jungle (Exhibit)
item.media:credit: Guarionex Rodriguez for The New York Times

item.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Mistook Her Optimism for an Act’
item.description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: The Unforgettable Best in Show Finalists at the 2026 Westminster Dog Show
item.description: Antenna ears, floofy coats, glittery barrettes and more.
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk
item.media:credit: Lanna Apisukh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Penny, a Doberman pinscher who took the top prize at this year’s Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, with her spoils.

item.title: ‘Bridgerton’ Tackles the Orgasm Gap
item.description: Sex therapists say a character’s struggle to reach her “pinnacle” could help viewers better understand women’s sexuality.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: Should I Reach Out to a Young Person Who Ghosted My Elderly Mother?
item.description: A reader weighs getting involved in her 88-year-old mother’s withered friendship with a younger woman, who abruptly stopped making plans with her three years ago.
item.dc:creator: Philip Galanes
item.media:credit: Miguel Porlan

item.title: The Real Story Behind Jennette McCurdy’s Novel ‘Half His Age’
item.description: McCurdy’s new book is a work of fiction, but writing it helped her work through some complicated memories from her own life.
item.dc:creator: Anna Martin
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Background: Brian Rea; Inset photo: Victoria Stevens

item.title: For a Long Valentine’s Weekend, 6 Wellness Getaways
item.description: Couples have three days to celebrate togetherness this year, and resorts and hotels are going all out on the feel-good front.
item.dc:creator: Amy Thomas

item.title: Wager, a smooth fox terrier, wins the terrier group.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:credit: Lanna Apisukh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amy Rutherford leading Wager, who turned 2 just last week, on one of the most successful walks of his young life.

item.title: Catherine O’Hara, Star of ‘Best in Show,’ Honored in Westminster Tribute
item.description: Fans remembered the actress, who died last week at 71, for her role as the doting owner of a Norwich terrier destined for glory in the movie, a sendup of dog show culture.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:credit: Doane Gregory/Online USA, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Catherine O’Hara as Cookie Fleck, a Florida dog lover with a past, in Christopher Guest’s “Best in Show.” Her hapless husband, Gerry (Eugene Levy), rose to the occasion in the film’s fictional dog show.

item.title: Penny, a Doberman pinscher, wins the working group.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:credit: Lanna Apisukh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andy Linton and Penny emerged victorious from a competitive working group.

item.title: Cota, a Chesapeake Bay retriever, wins the sporting group.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:credit: Lanna Apisukh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cota (above, with his handler, Devon Kipp Levy) bested his fellow athletes in the sporting group to be named best in group.

item.title: The top judge is partial to Pekingese, but only at home.
item.description: David Fitzpatrick has led two Pekingese to Westminster glory, but when it comes time to select best in show, he knows “how to appreciate all dogs.”
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wasabi (above in 2021, being held like a vintage bread box bought for a song at an estate sale) is the second Pekingese to capture best in show at Westminster for David Fitzpatrick.

item.title: A lifelong lover of Dobermans reclaims best in show after 37 years.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall and Callie Holtermann
item.media:credit: Lanna Apisukh for The New York Times

item.title: Four dogs have already advanced to best in show judging.
item.description: The winners of Monday’s hound, toy, non-sporting and herding group judging will return on Tuesday night.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:credit: Lanna Apisukh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Willy Santiago led Zaida the Afghan hound — along with her several Rapunzels’ worth of blond tresses — around the ring. She was named best in the hound group on Monday.

item.title: Last year, Monty trounced the competition.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie/The New York Times
item.media:description: The A.K.C. breed standard for the giant schnauzer calls for ears “set high on the skull and carried perpendicularly.” Above, the ears of a champion.

item.title: Tom Britt, Designer of Larger-Than-Life Interiors, Dies at 89
item.description: A master of the grand gesture, he was as theatrical as his rooms, which were inspired by French chateaus and Italian palazzos. As he put it, “Why be ordinary?”
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

item.title: ’The Devil Wears Prada 2’ Trailer Promises a Nostalgia Trip
item.description: But will it be delightful or depressing to watch Andy and Miranda navigate the current fashion media landscape?
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk

item.title: Everyone Is Missing the Point About the ‘Melania’ Movie
item.description: It’s not really a movie at all. It’s a marketing deck.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Melania Trump at the screening of “Melania” at the Kennedy Center last week.

item.title: Street Style Look of the Week: Vintage Fur Coats
item.description: A couple strolling through London were sporting fuzzy secondhand coats.
item.dc:creator: Simbarashe Cha

item.title: Westminster Dog Show 2026: Behind-the-Scenes Photos
item.description: Brushing, panting, licking and leaping: Here’s what we saw backstage, where show dogs could let their fur down before taking to the ring.
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk, Lanna Apisukh and Amir Hamja
item.category: Javits, Jacob K, Convention Center (Manhattan, NY)
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: A well-groomed bichon frisé will stand out almost anywhere, but against the purple carpeting in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, one can truly pop.

item.title: How to Watch the 2026 Westminster Dog Show
item.description: Everything you (and your dog) need to know about the competition, now in its 150th outing.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie/The New York Times
item.media:description: Monty, a giant schnauzer who enjoys chewing on soccer balls, won best in show at last year’s Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

item.title: Unzipped, Unplugged and Still Unfiltered, Darling
item.description: As he celebrates his 10th year at Café Carlyle — and his quippy turn in “Marty Supreme” — we catch up with Isaac Mizrahi.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Iredale
item.media:credit: Justin J Wee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Isaac Supreme: Mr. Mizrahi at home in January.

item.title: John Forté, Who Forged a Hip-Hop Redemption Tale, Dies at 50
item.description: He seemed destined for a glittering career, working with the Fugees and solo, and then landed in prison. After his sentence was commuted, he clawed his way back.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby/Getty Images
item.media:description: John Forté in 2010. His rise in the music industry was swift, but his fall came just as quickly, when he was convicted of acting as a middleman in a scheme to transport $1.4 million worth of liquid cocaine.

item.title: A Closer Look at Mamdani’s Custom Carhartt Jacket
item.description: As he dealt with a major snowstorm, Mayor Zohran Mamdani appeared in a personalized Carhartt jacket designed with help from the first lady.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:credit: Bing Guan/Reuters
item.media:description: Speaking to New Yorkers about a recent snowstorm, Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York City wore a Carhartt jacket with embroidery that included a throwback municipal logo, which is also featured on merchandise from Only NY, a local skate brand.

item.title: Are Models Getting Even Skinnier?
item.description: The era of size inclusivity is seemingly over. Our critic traces the shift and hopes designers might learn from it.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Simbarashe Cha/The New York Times
item.media:description: The backlash to “wokeness” has swept up size inclusivity on the runway.

item.title: Will the Spirit of 1976 Come to 2026?
item.description: Bicentennial celebrations across America were spirited and joyous. As the semiquincentennial approaches, there’s a different mood.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz
item.media:credit: Pictorial Parade/Getty Images
item.media:description: Buster Smith, in Revolutionary garb, took part in an anti-big-business protest held by the People’s Bicentennial Commission at the Washington Monument on July 4, 1976.
